text: really really lately hi everybody
Anthony Pham tanto here the Internet's
busiest music nerd yep and it's time for
an album review Tom Waits that is me
Tom Waits in my opinion is one of modern
music's most eccentric and standout
songwriters he's a guy who in a way I
have to thank for kind of changing the
way I listen to music change the things
that I look for in music sometimes to
his stuff over the years has helped me
appreciate things like grit and abstract
lyricism and darkness and odd sounds
when I first heard of this guy it was
when he dropped his album real gone in
2004 not his greatest LP but at that
time my musical world was very very
small so being introduced to Tom Waits
was kind of like dropping a boulder in a
kiddie pool
he just didn't sound like anything I had
ever heard before in my life so I became
obsessed and learned his influences and
read interviews and books and managed to
get a copy of nearly every album he ever
made between the time he put out real
gone and then released orphans just two
years later now when I first heard bad
as me was coming out I was you know kind
of afraid to listen to it not as a fan
but because I knew I was going to have
to review it and I was going to have to
battle myself either in one direction or
the other and try to either not be a
fanboy or try to not be too negative
because I'm so enamored with Tom's
previous works but to be completely
honest in my first few listens to this
LP I was pretty disappointed and I still
am to an extent I don't think bad as me
as a terrible album but what made me
kind of disappointed is that in my
opinion every Tom Waits album up until
this point especially everything that
came after rain dogs has a particular
feel to it that makes it different from
every other Tom Waits album I think bad
as me is
packing that mule variations to me is
very kind of worn and dusty I just kind
of get this like this old-school
hitchhiker kind of feel from it bone
machine is loud and clanging and bending
I just kind of feel like I'm like in
some underground cave and it's really
dark and they're monsters in there it's
kind of freaky Alice is incredibly dark
and depressing blood-money really barks
with intensity it's just smothered in
blood and cigar smoke it's a really kind
of murderous album and real gone is so
low fie and fuzzy really Tom Waits is
most noisy album yet in my opinion and I
think there are some common threads that
run through each album like Tom Waits
voice piano ballad screamers and singers
bangers and clangers and on bad as me I
don't feel like Tom is offering me a new
style at least not for an entire album
anyway I feel like for the most part bad
as me is almost kind of like a
retrospective of Tom looking back
revisiting past sounds and just kind of
looking at how bad he's been over the
years the really slow bluesy feel of
raised right men would have fit in
really well with heart attack and vine
if it wasn't for that
screaming organ in the background payme
is a really nostalgic waltz and New
Year's Eve has the kind of storytelling
that reminds me a lot of Frank's wild
years especially since pay me has lyrics
about Fame and the stage lasts leaf and
face to the highway are kind of forlorn
and and very subtle and quiet I could
just hear the wind blowing and the
tumbleweeds going by on these tracks and
it really makes me feel like I'm
listening the mule variations kiss me
reminds me of these really long
wandering love ballads that he used to
write a lot more way back in the day on
albums like Blue Valentine I could go on
forever
none of these revisits really bugged me
except for the song satisfied which
sounds exactly like the song big black
Mariah from Rain Dogs you can pretty
much sing the hook from one song over
the other without any hitches overall
I'm not really feeling a flavor from
album or an overall style to me right
now this album kind of feels like a
mixed bag a lot like orphans was except
you're only really getting one albums
length of tracks only a few spots only a
few here feel kind of new to me I love
the song get lost because it's got this
rockabilly feel to it and then it kind
of struck me why haven't I heard Tom go
down this direction more before the song
bad is me goes nuts with his voice that
Tom Waits kind of saves only for special
occasions and the song hell broke loose
man that thing is noisy as hell has
these guitars in the background just
pumping in a way that kind of reminds me
of industrial music it bangs it screams
and is an interesting reflection about
war and paints a story about this
military where Tom is singing from the
perspective of a soldier talking about
getting off meth and bringing up suicide
bombs so because I feel like I'm hearing
a lot of things on this album I've heard
before I think what makes this thing
enjoyable what it really comes down to
is just the tunes the melodies the hooks
the lyrics the song raised right men is
is is pretty dark and and I think in a
way funny
it's just about how a good man is hard
to find talking at the same time is kind
of about how the problems of the world
are being overlooked because everybody
is talking at the same time Tom sings
and this really creepy falsetto that I
love that he doesn't do all too often in
the woodwinds that come past the hooks
on that track are really beautiful and
on that track Tom drops a lyrical nugget
that reminds me that he is kind of a
lyrical double genius sometimes he says
everybody knows umbrellas cost more in
the rain but there are a good chunk of
tracks on here that just leave me
wanting more the song kiss me I kind of
roll my eyes at some of the lyrics on
that track I've never really known Tom
to throw out that many cliches in one
song and the song back in the crowd
feels kind of just dry and empty in a
way that leaves me underwhelmed it's one
of the cleaner and more sanitized Tom
Waits songs I've ever heard there's not
a speck
dirt insight in any direction I think
there's kind of a funny metaphor in the
hook but outside of that it's not really
doing a lot for me and the song last
leaf to me is a little kind of
long-winded
I guess the guitars don't do that much
for me and the background vocals
intertwine with the lead vocals in a
really awkward way that's distracting
more than it is complementing I mean if
you're the last leaf on the tree who is
that singing
I think this LP is kind of a sidestep
definitely not a step backwards in my
opinion tom has not lost his musical
flavor at all he's always really had
obvious influences like Howlin wolf and
Captain Beefheart and blues artists like
Muddy Waters and jazz artists like Louie
Armstrong of course he's really
influenced by gospel music too but
overall when Tom Waits makes a song it
sounds like a Tom Waits song despite the
fact that there's really no cohesive
feel between these tracks for me I'm
feeling a strong six to a light seven on
this I thought it was really good and
worth checking out but it's definitely
not one of my favorites in his catalogue
but what do you think of this thing do
you love it do you hate it why and what
do you think I should review next
anthony Fantan Oh Tom Waits
[Music]
